title: Messi and Alba Suspended for Missing MLS All-Star Game

Lionel Messi and his Inter Miami team-mate Jordi Alba get one-match bans for skipping Major League Soccer's All-Star game earlier this week.

title: Cambodia Seeks Immediate UN-Backed Ceasefire with Thailand Amid Deadly Clashes
snippets: Thailand has not yet commented on the proposal, as fighting continues for a third day with 32 confirmed killed.

Thousands of people have been evacuated from either side of the border, while fighting has left at least 32 people dead

Cambodia wants an “immediate ceasefire” with Thailand, the country’s envoy to the United Nations has said, as
More than 100,000 people have been displaced in the deadliest conflict between the two nations in 14 years.
titles: Cambodia calls for immediate ceasefire with Thailand as death toll rises
Cambodia calls for ‘immediate ceasefire’ with Thailand as deadly clashes enter a third day
Thailand Warns of War With Cambodia as Deadly Clashes Enter 2nd Day
summary: Cambodia has called for an "immediate ceasefire" with Thailand at the United Nations amid ongoing fighting that has resulted in at least 32 deaths. This conflict, the deadliest in 14 years between the two nations, has led to the displacement of more than 100,000 people. Thousands have been evacuated from both sides of the border. Thailand has yet to respond to the ceasefire proposal.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the ongoing conflict between Cambodia and Thailand, including the call for a ceasefire and the impact of the conflict on the local population. However, it does not provide any solutions or in-depth analysis of the causes or potential outcomes of the conflict.

title: Neanderthals' Diet Likely Included Maggots, New Research Suggests
snippets: It has been claimed Neanderthals ate a huge amount of meat based on isotope ratios in their bones – but the explanation could instead be a diet rich in maggots

Researchers believe humans’ closest relatives may have stored meat from their kills for months before eating it

For hungry Neanderthals, there was more on the menu than wild mammals, roasted pigeon, seafood and plants. Chemical signatures in the ancient bones point to a nutritious and somew
titles: Neanderthals were probably maggot-munchers, not hyper-carnivores
Neanderthals were not ‘hypercarnivores’ and feasted on maggots, scientists say
summary: Recent research suggests Neanderthals' diet may have been rich in maggots, not just large quantities of meat as previously thought, based on isotope ratios in their bones. This indicates they possibly stored meat for months, which attracted maggots, adding a nutritious source to their diet. This challenges earlier assumptions about Neanderthal dietary habits, highlighting a diverse menu that included wild mammals, seafood, plants, and now, maggots.
constructiveness_reason: The story clearly highlights new research findings that challenge previous assumptions about Neanderthal dietary habits. This could empower readers with a deeper understanding of human evolution and anthropology. However, the story could have been more constructive if it had explained the implications of these findings in a broader context.

title: Probiotic-Fermented Stevia Found to Target Pancreatic Cancer Cells
snippets: Fermenting stevia with a banana leaf-derived probiotic turns it into a powerful cancer-fighting agent that kills pancreatic cancer cells while sparing healthy ones. The secret lies in a metabolite called CAME, produced through microbial transformation.
titles: This sugar substitute does more than sweeten — it kills cancer cells
summary: Researchers have discovered that fermenting stevia with a probiotic derived from banana leaves produces a metabolite named CAME. This substance has been found to selectively kill pancreatic cancer cells without harming healthy cells, marking a significant advancement in cancer treatment options.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on an innovation in the field of cancer treatment. It provides actionable insights for those in the medical field and gives a deeper understanding of a potential new treatment for pancreatic cancer.

title: New Genetic Test Doubles Accuracy in Predicting Childhood Obesity Risk
snippets: What if we could predict obesity before it ever takes hold? A global team has created a genetic test that forecasts a child’s risk of adult obesity before age five—years before other factors kick in. By analyzing data from over five million people, their polygenic risk score doubles the predictive p
titles: This DNA test can predict if a 5-year-old will be obese as an adult
summary: A global research team developed a genetic test capable of predicting a child's risk of adult obesity before the age of five. The test, which analyzes data from over five million people, utilizes a polygenic risk score to double the accuracy of existing predictive methods for obesity. This advancement could enable earlier interventions to prevent obesity in individuals identified at risk.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it highlights progress in predicting childhood obesity risk. It provides useful information about a new genetic test that could lead to early interventions, thereby empowering readers with knowledge that can be used to make informed decisions.
